label: Predictive Maintenance & Work Orders
description: IoT sensor monitoring with predictive failure alerts 7-14 days ahead and auto-generated work orders reducing unplanned downtime 40-60% and maintenance costs 30-50% versus reactive maintenance.

traditional.workflow: 1. Equipment operates normally until failure occurs (HVAC stops cooling, elevator breaks down). 2. Employee discovers failure and reports to facilities via phone or email: 'AC not working in Building 2'. 3. Facilities admin manually creates work order, assigns to technician. 4. Technician dispatched 2-4 hours later, diagnoses failed compressor requiring replacement part. 5. Part ordered, arrives in 2-5 days, technician returns to complete repair. 6. Total downtime 2-7 days due to reactive response. 7. 60-80% of downtime is unplanned (run-to-failure maintenance).
constraints: Reactive maintenance (fix after failure, no prevention)
60-80% unplanned downtime due to run-to-failure approach
2-7 day downtime for repairs requiring parts (not stocked on-site)
Manual work order creation delays response by 2-4 hours
No early warning of impending failures (discover when equipment stops)
High maintenance costs (emergency repairs, overtime labor, rush shipping)

agentic.workflow: 1. Predictive Maintenance Agent monitors IoT sensors on equipment: HVAC compressor vibration increased 30%, operating temperature elevated 15°F above normal baseline. 2. Agent applies ML model predicting compressor failure in 7-14 days with 85% confidence. 3. Work Order Automation Agent generates preventive work order automatically: 'HVAC Compressor - Predicted Failure in 10 days, schedule replacement before breakdown'. 4. Agent checks parts inventory, auto-orders compressor if not in stock (arrives in 2-3 days, before predicted failure). 5. Agent assigns work order to certified HVAC technician with availability during predicted timeframe. 6. Technician replaces compressor proactively during scheduled maintenance window (no unplanned downtime). 7. 40-60% unplanned downtime reduction and 30-50% maintenance cost savings through predictive intervention before failures occur.
dataSources: IoT sensor data (vibration, temperature, pressure, current draw)
Equipment operating baselines and normal ranges
Historical equipment failure patterns and fault signatures
Work order history with failure modes and resolution times
Parts inventory availability and lead times
Technician skills, certifications, and availability
Maintenance schedules and downtime windows
benefits: 40-60% unplanned downtime reduction through predictive maintenance
30-50% maintenance cost savings (avoid emergency repairs, overtime, rush shipping)
7-14 day advance warning enables proactive intervention before failures
Auto-generated work orders eliminate 2-4 hour manual creation delay
Equipment lifespan extended 20-30% through condition-based maintenance
Parts pre-ordered before failure (in stock when technician arrives)

quickWins: Deploy IoT sensors on top 10 critical assets (HVAC, elevators, chillers)
Implement vibration and temperature monitoring with threshold alerts
Enable auto work order generation for sensor alert triggers
prerequisites: Modern CMMS (Maximo, UpKeep, Fiix) with API and automation
IoT sensors retrofitted on critical equipment
IoT platform for sensor data aggregation (Azure IoT, AWS IoT)
ML model development for failure prediction by equipment type
Parts inventory system integration for auto-ordering
Technician mobile app for work order execution
Historical equipment failure data (12-24 months) for ML training

label: Space Planning & Utilization
description: Real-time occupancy sensors with ML-powered space recommendations and hoteling optimization achieving 75-85% desk utilization versus 40-60% manual planning and 20-40% real estate cost reduction.

traditional.workflow: 1. Office space allocated by headcount: 100 employees = 100 desks (1:1 ratio regardless of actual presence). 2. Utilization unknown (no tracking or measurement of desk occupancy). 3. Quarterly manual headcount audit: 'Engineering grew from 100 to 120, we need 20 more desks'. 4. Facilities manager requests more space, commercial real estate broker finds additional floor (expensive). 5. Space planning reactive (add space when out of room, not proactive). 6. Desk utilization actually 40-60% due to remote work, travel, meetings (paying for 100 desks, using 40-60). 7. Post-COVID hybrid work worsens utilization to 20-40% (employees in office 2-3 days/week).
constraints: 1:1 desk-to-employee ratio ignores actual utilization (40-60% occupancy)
No real-time occupancy data (utilization unknown)
Space planning reactive based on headcount (add space when full)
Post-COVID hybrid work drives utilization to 20-40% (wasted real estate)
No hoteling or hot-desking (employees claim desks even when absent)
Real estate costs high (paying for unused space)

agentic.workflow: 1. Occupancy Analysis Agent monitors occupancy sensors in real-time: tracks desk, office, and conference room usage by day, time, and employee. 2. Agent analyzes utilization patterns: 'Engineering desks utilized 35% on average (Mon-Tue 60%, Wed-Thu 40%, Fri 10%)'. 3. Space Utilization Agent recommends hoteling transition: 'Engineering needs 70 desks for 120 employees (1.7:1 ratio) based on hybrid work patterns'. 4. Agent designs neighborhood seating: clusters teams together in hoteling zones, reserves 20% dedicated desks for full-time onsite staff. 5. Agent implements smart booking system: employees reserve desks via app, check-in via badge swipe, auto-release after 15 min if no-show. 6. Agent optimizes space portfolio: 'Consolidate 3 floors into 2 floors, sublease 1 floor, save $2M/year in real estate costs'. 7. 75-85% desk utilization improvement and 20-40% real estate cost reduction through data-driven space optimization.
dataSources: Occupancy sensor data (desks, offices, conference rooms)
Badge access swipe data (entry, exit, location)
Room and desk booking system reservations
Employee work schedules and hybrid work policies
Real estate lease data (sq ft, cost, expiration)
Headcount data and growth projections
Space inventory (floor plans, desk count, room capacity)
benefits: 20-40% real estate cost reduction through space consolidation and subleases
75-85% desk utilization improvement (vs 40-60% pre-COVID, 20-40% post-COVID)
Hoteling enables 1.5-2:1 employee-to-desk ratio (60-70 desks for 120 employees)
Data-driven space planning vs reactive headcount-based approach
Smart booking prevents double-bookings and no-shows (auto-release)
Neighborhood seating maintains team collaboration in hoteling environment

quickWins: Deploy occupancy sensors on one pilot floor to measure utilization
Implement desk booking app for hoteling trial with voluntary participants
Create occupancy dashboard showing real-time and historical utilization
prerequisites: Workplace management platform (Robin, Envoy, OfficeSpace)
Occupancy sensors deployed (Density, VergeSense, Butlr)
Badge access system integration for check-in data
Desk booking mobile app for employee self-service
Floor plan digitization with desk/room inventory
Hybrid work policy defined (office days, flexibility)
Change management for hoteling adoption (executive sponsorship)

label: Energy Management & Sustainability
description: Real-time energy monitoring with AI-optimized HVAC/lighting and predictive demand management achieving 15-30% energy cost reduction and real-time carbon footprint tracking versus monthly bills.

traditional.workflow: 1. Utility bills received monthly via mail or email (electricity, gas, water). 2. Facilities admin manually enters bills into spreadsheet for tracking and budgeting. 3. Energy consumption analyzed at month-end (too late to take corrective action). 4. HVAC controlled by fixed schedules: on at 6am, off at 6pm Monday-Friday (runs even when building empty). 5. Lighting controlled by manual switches (employees forget to turn off, lights on all night). 6. No real-time energy visibility (discover waste after the fact in monthly bill). 7. Sustainability reporting manual: annual carbon footprint calculation in Excel from utility bills.
constraints: Monthly utility bills too late for corrective action (waste discovered after it occurs)
Fixed HVAC schedules waste energy (runs when building empty nights/weekends)
Manual lighting control (employees forget, lights on unnecessarily)
No real-time energy monitoring (visibility delayed by 30 days)
20-30% energy waste from lights/HVAC running when spaces unoccupied
Carbon footprint calculated annually in Excel (time-consuming, inaccurate)

agentic.workflow: 1. Energy Monitoring Agent tracks consumption in real-time via smart meters: electricity, gas, water by building, floor, department, equipment. 2. Energy Optimization Agent adjusts HVAC based on occupancy sensors: 'Conference room 3B empty for 2 hours, reduce HVAC setpoint to save energy'. 3. Agent optimizes HVAC based on weather forecast: 'Pre-cool building at 5am using off-peak rates before heat wave hits, reduce afternoon cooling load'. 4. Lighting Control Agent dims/turns off lights automatically when occupancy sensors detect empty spaces. 5. Demand Response Agent reduces load during peak pricing: curtails non-essential HVAC, shifts equipment operation to off-peak hours, saves 20-40% on demand charges. 6. Sustainability Analytics Agent calculates carbon emissions automatically in real-time: 'Current monthly emissions 150 tons CO2e, down 25% vs last year, on track for net-zero by 2030 target'. 7. 15-30% energy cost reduction and real-time carbon tracking vs monthly bill approach.
dataSources: Smart meter data (real-time electricity, gas, water consumption)
Utility bills and rate schedules (time-of-use, demand charges)
Weather data (temperature, humidity, forecast)
Occupancy sensor data (building, floor, room presence)
HVAC operating schedules and setpoint configurations
Lighting control system status (on/off, dimming levels)
Carbon emission factors by energy source (grid electricity, natural gas)
Sustainability goals and net-zero targets
benefits: 15-30% energy cost reduction through HVAC/lighting optimization
Real-time energy monitoring vs 30-day delayed monthly bills
Occupancy-based HVAC/lighting control eliminates 60-80% of waste
Weather-based optimization (pre-cool, pre-heat) reduces peak demand
20-40% demand charge reduction through peak shaving and load curtailment
Real-time carbon footprint tracking vs annual manual calculation

quickWins: Deploy smart meters for real-time energy monitoring by building
Implement occupancy-based lighting control with auto-off when spaces empty
Enable HVAC schedule optimization (off during unoccupied hours)
prerequisites: Energy management platform (EnergyCAP, Schneider EcoStruxure)
Smart meters installed (or utility AMI data access)
Building Management System (BMS) integration for HVAC control
Occupancy sensors deployed for presence detection
Weather API integration for forecast-based optimization
Utility rate schedule data for demand response optimization
Sustainability goals and carbon reduction targets defined

label: Vendor & Contractor Management
description: Centralized vendor portal with auto-invoice matching and performance scorecards achieving 70-85% invoice processing time reduction and 100% compliance visibility versus email-based tracking.

traditional.workflow: 1. Vendor selection via informal email-based RFP process. 2. Contracts stored in filing cabinets or shared drives (no central repository). 3. Vendor work assigned via phone calls or emails (no systematic tracking). 4. Invoices received via email or mail, manually entered into AP system for payment. 5. Invoice reconciliation manual: facilities manager compares invoice to work order notes, checks rates against contract (2-4 hours per invoice). 6. Insurance certificates tracked in spreadsheet (if at all), many vendors operating with expired coverage (compliance risk). 7. No vendor performance tracking (renewals based on relationships, not data).
constraints: Email-based vendor management fragmented and inefficient
No centralized contract repository (contracts lost, terms forgotten)
Manual invoice reconciliation takes 2-4 hours per invoice
Insurance certificate compliance 60-70% (expired coverage creates liability)
No vendor performance tracking (quality, timeliness, cost variance)
Invoice disputes common (10-15% of invoices) due to rate mismatches

agentic.workflow: 1. Vendor Management Agent provides centralized portal where vendors submit documents: W-9, insurance certificates, banking info, certifications. 2. Agent validates insurance certificates: checks coverage amounts meet requirements (GL $2M, Workers Comp, Auto), sends renewal reminders 30 days before expiration. 3. Work order assigned to vendor, vendor accepts and tracks progress in portal. 4. Invoice Processing Agent receives invoice, auto-matches to work order and contract rates: 'Invoice $1,200 for HVAC repair matches Work Order #54321, contract rate $150/hour × 8 hours = $1,200, approved for payment'. 5. Performance Monitoring Agent tracks metrics: 'ABC Mechanical: 95% on-time completion, 4.8/5 quality rating, 5% cost variance vs estimates - Platinum tier vendor'. 6. Agent flags compliance issues: 'XYZ Electrical insurance certificate expired 15 days ago - block new work orders until renewed'. 7. 70-85% invoice processing time reduction and 100% compliance visibility through automation.
dataSources: Vendor master data (contact info, capabilities, certifications)
Vendor contracts with pricing, SLAs, and terms
Work order assignments and completion data
Invoice details (line items, rates, quantities)
Insurance certificates and expiration dates
Performance feedback (quality ratings, on-time completion)
Cost variance analysis (estimated vs actual)
benefits: 70-85% invoice processing time reduction (15-30 min vs 2-4 hours) through auto-matching
100% insurance compliance visibility vs 60-70% manual tracking
Invoice disputes reduced 80% through automated rate validation
Vendor performance scorecards enable data-driven renewals
Compliance blocking prevents work assignment to non-compliant vendors
Centralized vendor portal improves vendor experience and response time

quickWins: Deploy vendor portal for self-service document submission
Implement insurance certificate tracking with auto-renewal reminders
Enable invoice auto-matching to contract rates and work orders
prerequisites: Vendor management platform (Coupa, SAP Ariba, Avetta)
Vendor inventory and contract digitization
Integration with CMMS for work order data
AP system integration for invoice processing
Insurance verification service for certificate validation
Performance criteria and scorecard methodology defined
Vendor onboarding and training for portal adoption

label: Workplace Safety & Incident Tracking
description: Mobile incident reporting with real-time hazard detection and predictive safety analytics achieving 30-50% incident reduction and real-time compliance versus quarterly safety audits.

traditional.workflow: 1. Employee witnesses safety incident (slip, fall, near-miss) and fills out paper incident report. 2. Paper form submitted to facilities manager, manually entered into spreadsheet or safety database. 3. Safety audits conducted quarterly using paper checklists (blocked exits, missing fire extinguishers, trip hazards). 4. Audit findings documented in Word report, shared with facilities team, corrective actions assigned manually. 5. OSHA reporting done annually or after major incidents (late, reactive compliance). 6. No predictive analytics (incidents discovered after they occur, patterns unidentified). 7. Safety training annual classroom sessions with no tracking of completion or effectiveness.
constraints: Paper incident reports create 2-5 day reporting delay
Quarterly safety audits miss hazards that emerge between audits
No real-time hazard detection (discover issues reactively)
OSHA compliance reactive (report after incident, not prevent)
No incident pattern analysis (recurring hazards unidentified)
Safety training annual with no completion tracking

agentic.workflow: 1. Safety Incident Agent provides mobile app for employees to report incidents in real-time: photo of hazard, location pin, description, severity. 2. Agent routes incident to facilities for immediate action: 'Trip hazard reported in Building 2 Lobby - dispatch technician now'. 3. Hazard Detection Agent analyzes IoT sensors: 'Temperature in chemical storage room exceeds 90°F safe limit - alert facilities and safety officer'. 4. Agent conducts digital safety inspections: facilities staff uses mobile checklist app, automatic photo documentation, GPS-stamped location data. 5. Predictive Safety Agent identifies patterns: 'Slip/fall incidents increased 40% in Building 3 during winter months - recommend anti-slip floor treatment before next season'. 6. Agent tracks corrective actions: '15 hazards identified last month, 12 resolved (80%), 3 overdue - escalate to facilities manager'. 7. 30-50% incident reduction and real-time compliance through predictive analytics and mobile reporting.
dataSources: Incident reports from mobile app (photos, location, description)
IoT sensor data (temperature, gas detection, humidity)
Safety inspection checklists and findings
Corrective action tracking and completion status
Historical incident patterns by location and time
OSHA reporting requirements and deadlines
Safety training completion records
benefits: 30-50% incident reduction through predictive analytics and pattern recognition
Real-time incident reporting (2-5 days → <1 hour) via mobile app
Continuous safety monitoring vs quarterly audit approach
Proactive hazard detection via IoT sensors (temperature, gas, humidity)
OSHA compliance automated (real-time reporting vs reactive)
Corrective action tracking ensures hazards resolved, not ignored

quickWins: Deploy mobile incident reporting app for employees and facilities staff
Implement digital safety inspection checklists replacing paper forms
Enable IoT sensors for critical safety parameters (temperature, gas detection)
prerequisites: Safety management platform (Intelex, Cority) with mobile app
IoT sensors for hazard detection (temperature, gas, humidity)
Mobile app development for incident reporting and inspections
Integration with OSHA reporting systems
Historical incident data for pattern analysis and ML training
Safety inspection checklist digitization
Employee training on mobile incident reporting process

label: Meeting Room & Resource Booking
description: Smart booking with occupancy validation and auto-release on no-show achieving 90% no-show elimination and 30-50% meeting room efficiency improvement versus manual calendar booking.

traditional.workflow: 1. Employee books conference room via Outlook/Google Calendar for 2pm-3pm meeting. 2. Employee forgets about meeting or decides to meet virtually instead (30-40% no-show rate). 3. Booked conference room sits empty while other employees can't find available space ('all rooms booked' but many empty). 4. Double-bookings occur when calendar integration fails or employees override system. 5. AV equipment requests manual (employee emails facilities: 'Need projector for 2pm meeting'). 6. No visibility into actual room utilization (30-40% of bookings result in no-shows, 20-30% of meetings end early but room held until scheduled end). 7. Conference rooms overbuilt relative to actual demand (wasted real estate).
constraints: 30-40% no-show rate wastes meeting room capacity
Manual booking doesn't validate actual usage (rooms held, not used)
Double-bookings and conflicts frustrate employees
AV equipment requests manual (email to facilities)
No utilization data (can't optimize room count or size)
Meetings ending early don't release rooms (held until scheduled end)

agentic.workflow: 1. Smart Booking Agent enables employees to find rooms via app: filters by capacity, location, AV equipment, availability. 2. Employee books room for 2pm-3pm, agent requires check-in via badge swipe or mobile app within 10 minutes of meeting start. 3. Resource Optimization Agent monitors occupancy sensors: detects room 3B booked at 2pm but no one entered by 2:10pm - auto-releases room, notifies booker of cancellation. 4. Agent detects meeting ended early: occupancy sensors show room empty at 2:35pm (25 min remaining) - releases room, makes available for others. 5. Agent manages AV equipment automatically: employee selects 'projector required' when booking, facilities receives auto-notification to set up equipment. 6. Agent provides room utilization analytics: 'Conference rooms utilized 75% on average after no-show elimination, Meeting Room C underutilized at 40% - consider converting to focus room'. 7. 90% no-show elimination and 30-50% efficiency improvement through smart booking and auto-release.
dataSources: Calendar booking data (reservations, duration, attendees)
Occupancy sensor data (room entry, exit, presence)
Badge access data for check-in validation
Room inventory (capacity, location, AV equipment)
Meeting room utilization history
AV equipment availability and setup requirements
Employee location and preferences
benefits: 90% no-show elimination through check-in requirement and auto-release
30-50% meeting room efficiency improvement (utilization 70-80% vs 40-60%)
Auto-release on no-show makes rooms available for others (reduce 'all booked' frustration)
Early meeting end detection releases rooms immediately (vs held until scheduled end)
AV equipment auto-setup eliminates manual email requests
Utilization analytics enable data-driven decisions (convert underutilized rooms)
metrics: AV equipment request time: Automatic (booking time)

quickWins: Deploy occupancy sensors in conference rooms for no-show detection
Implement auto-release policy (10-minute check-in window)
Enable room booking app with capacity, location, AV equipment filters
prerequisites: Room booking platform (Robin, Condeco, Teem) with automation
Occupancy sensors in conference rooms for presence detection
Calendar API integration (Google Workspace, Microsoft 365)
Badge access system integration for check-in validation
AV equipment inventory and setup procedures
No-show policy defined (auto-release after 10 min)
Employee communication and training on check-in requirement

label: Facilities Analytics & Reporting
description: Real-time dashboards with predictive analytics and automated cost center allocation enabling data-driven facilities decisions versus monthly spreadsheet reports.

traditional.workflow: 1. Facilities manager manually compiles data from multiple sources: CMMS for work orders, utility bills for energy, invoices for vendor costs, spreadsheets for space allocation. 2. Data consolidated in Excel, pivot tables created for analysis by building, department, cost category. 3. Monthly report created in PowerPoint: 'Last month facilities spent $500K (maintenance $200K, energy $150K, vendor costs $150K)'. 4. Report shows what happened (backward-looking) but no insights or recommendations. 5. Cost center allocation manual: facilities manager estimates department usage, allocates costs subjectively. 6. Report shared with leadership 2-3 weeks after month-end (too late for corrective action). 7. No predictive analytics (can't forecast future costs or issues).
constraints: Manual data consolidation from multiple sources (time-consuming, error-prone)
Monthly reporting cycle too slow for corrective action (2-3 weeks delayed)
Backward-looking only (what happened, not what will happen)
Cost center allocation manual and inaccurate (subjective estimates)
No predictive analytics or forecasting
Limited insights or recommendations (just data presentation)

agentic.workflow: 1. Facilities Analytics Agent integrates data sources automatically: CMMS, utility bills, vendor invoices, space management system, energy monitoring. 2. Agent generates real-time dashboard: facilities costs by building, department, category with trend analysis (up/down vs prior period). 3. Cost Allocation Agent assigns costs to departments automatically: energy based on floor space occupancy, maintenance based on work orders by location, shared costs by headcount. 4. Agent provides predictive analytics: 'HVAC maintenance costs trending 20% higher than budget - forecast $50K overspend by year-end, recommend preventive maintenance to reduce failures'. 5. Agent benchmarks performance: 'Energy cost per sq ft $2.30 vs industry average $2.80 (performing well), maintenance cost per sq ft $3.50 vs industry $2.50 (opportunity to optimize)'. 6. Agent generates executive-ready reports automatically: top cost drivers, KPI trends, budget variances, recommended actions. 7. Real-time visibility enables proactive facilities decisions vs reactive monthly reports.
dataSources: CMMS work order data (maintenance costs, labor, parts)
Utility bills and energy monitoring data (electricity, gas, water)
Vendor invoices and payment history
Space management system (occupancy, floor space by department)
Budget and forecast data by cost category
Industry benchmark data (cost per sq ft by category)
Headcount data for cost allocation
benefits: Real-time visibility vs 2-3 week delayed monthly reports
Automated cost allocation (95% accuracy vs 60-70% manual estimates)
Predictive analytics forecast budget variances before they occur
Benchmarking identifies improvement opportunities vs industry standards
Data consolidation automated (2-4 days → real-time)
Executive-ready reports with insights and recommendations, not just data

quickWins: Deploy BI dashboard with real-time facilities KPIs (cost, energy, maintenance)
Implement automated cost allocation by department based on floor space and headcount
Enable budget variance alerts when costs trending 10%+ over budget
prerequisites: BI platform (Tableau, Power BI, Qlik) with data warehouse
Integration with CMMS, utility bills, vendor invoices, space management
Cost center system for department allocation
Budget and forecast data for variance analysis
Industry benchmark data subscriptions
Executive dashboard design and KPI definition
Data governance for accuracy and consistency
